title: The Bombardment of Reims
author: Ferree, Barr, 1862-1924

quoteFirst: Chairs turned down for expected guests.  Three-pronged steel forks.  Cold supper from
quoteLast: Great, round, mahogany table, in the sitting-room, covered with papers.  In the morning, before and soon after breakfast, gentlemen reading the morning papers, while others wait for their chance, or try to pick out something from the papers of yesterday or longer ago.
title: Passages from the American Notebooks, Volume 1
author: Hawthorne, Nathaniel, 1804-1864

quoteFirst: during the northern monsoon; subject however to much irregularity. The land breeze sets in from
quoteLast: , and lasts till morning, increasing in force and regularity as we approach the equator; and its strength is generally in proportion to that of the sea breeze which precedes it. As in other tropical countries, the sea breeze prevails more in the hot, and the land breeze in the cold season of the year; they favour the appearance of certain maladies and check others, and constitute, after heat and moisture the chief element in the determination of disease—the salubrity of any country depending more, perhaps, on its winds than on its latitude.
title:
Brazil, the River Plate, and the Falkland Islands
With the Cape Horn route to Australia. Including notices of Lisbon, Madeira, the Canaries, and Cape Verde.
author: Hadfield, William, 1806-1887; Hotham, Charles [Illustrator]; Ouseley, William Gore, Sir, 1797-1866 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: There are cheap cafés, merry-go-rounds, and stands for dancing, where on Sunday may be seen the peculiar national dance of the Indians, _La Cueca_, where the couples face each other, handkerchief in hand, and dance with swaying gestures. In summer a biograph is usually in operation and twice a week a military band plays from
quoteLast: , when the park is often crowded. Near the entrance is a large open grass plot with a pavilion in the center, where a Military Review takes place Sept.
title: The South American Tour
author: Peck, Annie S. (Annie Smith), 1850-1935

title:
Report on the Migration of Birds in the Spring and Autumn of 1887. Ninth Report
(Vol. II, No. 4.)
author: Harvie-Brown, J. A. (John Alexander), 1844-1916; Barrington, Richard Manliffe, 1849-1915; Clarke, William Eagle, 1853-1938; Cordeaux, John, 1831-1899; More, Alexander Goodman, 1830-1895

quoteFirst: The instant at which this line is vertical over the pole is not the same on any two consecutive nights, since the stars advance each day 4 minutes on the sun. On the 21st of March the superior passage takes place at 5 minutes to 11 at night; on the following night four minutes earlier, or at
quoteLast: . In three months the culmination takes place 6 hours earlier, or at 5 minutes to 5. In six months, _i.e._ on Sept. 22, it culminates at 10.
title: Astronomical Myths: Based on Flammarions's "History of the Heavens"
author: Blake, J. F. (John Frederick), 1839-1906; Flammarion, Camille, 1842-1925

quoteFirst: The reporter adds the note:--"Starlings and Wheatears generally strike at night, when the wind shifts with rain. They probably leave resting-places, and, when once on wing, are attracted by the light." On Aug. 14th another single bird struck at 10.15 p.m.; wind light S.E., and fog: three more on 15th, from
quoteLast: ; wind the same, with haze. At Sumburgh Head, on Aug. 11th, one young bird struck; wind light N., and fog.
title: Report on the Migration of Birds in the Spring and Autumn of 1880. [Second Report]
author: Harvie-Brown, J. A. (John Alexander), 1844-1916; Cordeaux, John, 1831-1899; Kermode, P. M. C. (Philip Moore Callow), 1855?-1932

quoteFirst: by E., 2; O. M.) _Nash_ (_E._) L.H., Redwings passed to W. at 6.30 A.M. Song Thrushes (four killed) at 7.30 P.M.; Blackbirds (two killed) at 9.5 P.M. (E.N.E., 4; C. M.) _Breaksea_ L.V., Thrushes and Larks from
quoteLast: ; six killed. (E.N.E., 3; O. M.) _Bull Point_ L.H., a hen *Chaffinch killed at 3 A.M. (E., 3; B. C. M.) _Longships_ L.H., Puffins and Guillemots passing S. all day. (E., 3.) _Eddystone_ L.H.

quoteLast: , striking, five killed; stormy, wind N.E., overcast.

title: Desperate Remedies
author: Hardy, Thomas, 1840-1928

quoteFirst: He looked down the listings, and frowned. "All old movies. Still only one channel. Still only from
quoteLast: ." He gave it to her, turned away; then stopped and waited. He'd said the same thing last week. And she had said the films were all new to her.
title: Breakdown
author: Kastle, Herbert D., 1924-1987; Cowles [Illustrator]
